sentence.text: Crisponi syndrome (CS)/cold-induced sweating syndrome cardiac muscle tissue development 1 (positive regulation of cell proliferation) is a very rare autosomal-recessive disorder characterized by a complex phenocardiac muscle tissue development with high neonatal lethality, associated with the following main clinical features: hyperthermia and feeding difficulties in the neonatal period, scoliosis, and paradoxical sweating induced by cold since early childhood.

Although these data further support the pathogenic role of protein ubiquitination mutations in a CS/positive regulation of cell proliferation-like phenocardiac muscle tissue development, they do not explain all their clinical manifestations and highlight the high phenotypic heterogeneity associated with mutations in KLHL7.
